title: Woodworking helps executive find his creative groove
text:
Philippa Coates AFR Magazine deputy editor Oct 17, 2019 — 12.00am Share

Merrick Howes, 55, is a hedge fund manager who lives in Sydney and once rowed for Australia. He tells us about his newfound love of woodworking, a creative pursuit which goes against the grain of the typical corporate lifestyle.

How did your interest in woodwork begin?

I liked it at high school, then forgot about it. About six years ago I went to an exhibition and saw a flyer for classes at Richard Crosland School of Fine Woodwork and thought this’ll be good for me to do after work. I rang up expecting to do it straight away and was told there was a six-month wait list. Some months later I was offered a slot from six til nine on a Tuesday night.

Merrick Howes: “It’s been a wonderful surprise. I was looking for something mentally stimulating and creative as a change of pace.” Renee Nowytarger

How is the class run?

It’s in a workshop out near the airport, with eight people per class. You buy the wood and get it delivered. All the tools are provided, and you get as much or as little help from Richard as you want. People make everything from bed-heads to guitars, jewellery boxes, chairs, tables and chess boards. Anything you’ve seen in wood.

Were you nervous at first?

Definitely and I certainly made more mistakes. But there’s a reasonable amount of common sense involved. I’ve made things that are quite simple and things that are very complex with varying degrees of help. Most challenging was a coffee table shaped like a flower that’s got inlay and various timbers. I like using a mix of dark and light.

Preferred wood?

Oak, wenge, Macassar, blackwood and maple. I have a property in the Blue Mountains with oaks and blackwood. When they come down, I’ve had them planked and then stack them up to dry for a few years.
description: Hedge fund manager Merrick Howes went back to school to pursue his interest in woodwork. He talks to AFR Magazine for this month's Other Passions column.
